Interval between nearby-object scans, in milliseconds. Smaller values will update more frequently.
Interval between the more-intensive faraway-object scans, in milliseconds. Smaller values will update more frequently, but may have a performance cost.

Radius of the nearby-object scan in meters. Many things are based on this value, such as the distances at which markers fade out and scale up/down. It is recommended that you don't adjust this value, or do so in very small increments.

Radius of the faraway-object scan in meters, which is used to detect and initialize objects before their markers need to be shown. This also determines the distance at which the system cleans up markers that are no longer needed. \n \nThis is measured from the end of the near scan radius, but higher values may have a performance cost, and there is no benefit to setting them more than about 5m higher than the near radius.
Increase perception radius based on Skill System
Name of the skill used for this check
Scan radius multiplier per skill level

If Skill System integration is enabled, this setting controls the multiplier that is applied to the near scan radius per skill level, and effectively increases the player's "perception" range--within which dot markers can appear. \n \nAt Scavenging level 15 with the default multiplier of 0.2 and radius of 4, the final near scan radius would be 7m. A very high near scan radius can have a performance impact.

If you experience issues with object interaction not registering, try setting this keybind to something other than a variant of your primary interact key.\n
\nA double-tap of the primary interact key is unreliable, and not recommended.

With this flag on, DotMarks will log the most important events. If a problem only happened once, and this flag was not turned on first, the log will contain very little that is related to DotMarks--and it may not be useful at all.\n
\nIt is usually fine to leave this on while you play, if you suspect a problem and want to catch it.

When trying to reproduce a problem, please also enable this. It logs most of what DotMarks is doing internally, and it will ensure that the log contains the most detailed troubleshooting information.\n
\nThis setting is extremely noisy, and should not be left enabled during normal gameplay.
If enabled, the interaction dots themselves will be hidden, but the interaction UI will still be available.
Hide the custom primary interact UI
If enabled, the custom primary interact UI added by DotMarks will not be shown. The primary vanilla "use" function and prompts will still work normally.
Hide the custom secondary interact UI
If enabled, the custom secondary interact UI added by DotMarks will not be shown, and secondary interactions will not be available.

If enabled, any vanilla interact prompts (the text at the bottom of the screen) will be hidden if they have been replaced by a custom version. \n \nThis setting has no effect if the custom primary interaction UI is also hidden.
If enabled, the floating item names that appear when holding down the interact key will be hidden. This sets the g_draw_pickup_item_names cvar from the modded exes.
If enabled, will hide the white line connecting the dot to the interact prompt.
Show interaction prompt UI during FDDA animations
Interaction prompts disabled during FDDA animations

If enabled, the interact UI will still be shown during FDDA animations, and the next setting below controls whether it can be used. If you want to hide the prompt entirely during animations, disable this option.

If this option is enabled, the interact UI is disabled during FDDA animations, dimming and showing a "Too Busy" message until the current animation completes.
 
 
Disabling this option with the original FDDA will allow "animation canceling", skipping the current animation and immediately beginning the next. The sound effects will still play.
These settings adjust the positions of the interact prompts. These are canvas coordinates, which are 1024x768--not your screen resolution. Some may require a restart to take effect.
Adjust the prompt's position horizontally. Allowed values are -512 to 1024. \n \nDefault: -13
Adjust the prompt's position vertically. Allowed values are -384 to 768. \n \nDefault: 24
Adjust the prompt's position horizontally. Allowed values are -512 to 1024. \n \nDefault: -9
Adjust the prompt's position vertically. Allowed values are -384 to 768. \n \nDefault: 48

If this option is enabled, the custom interaction prompts will have a fixed screen position based on the offsets above, and the offsets are measured relative to the upper-left corner of the screen. 
 
By default, the prompts follow the position of their attached dotmark, and their offsets are measured from the position of that dot. 
 
You must restart/saveload your game for this setting to take effect.
Sets the alpha (transparency) channel for the main drop shadows underneath the interaction prompts or other UI elements. Set to zero to disable the main drop shadows.
Sets the visual style for the graphical "key" icons used as backgrounds for the keybind text on interaction prompts, or disables the backgrounds entirely.

This slider adjusts the size of the dot markers added to objects in the world. A value of 1 is their default intended size, while zero will hide these icons entirely. Other features of this addon, such as the text labels or secondary interaction, will not be affected.
Hide items marked as junk in Sorting Plus
If the Sorting Plus addon is installed, and an item has been marked as "junk", then a mark will not be shown for it.
Hidden items still show interaction prompts

If a marker is hidden for any reason, its interaction prompts will still be shown. \n \nNOTE: If this option is not enabled, hidden markers will not have any visible interaction prompts at all. This will not prevent you from picking them up if you want to, it just won't show the prompt.
Dead stalkers use PAW faction patches
If my Personal Adjustable Waypoint addon (PAW) is installed, this option will cause dead stalkers to show their faction patch instead of the dot marker icon.
Disables the subtle UI "blip" sound effect that plays when cycling the mouse wheel or during other similar events.
Body markers obey Milspec PDA rules
If my Milspec PDA addon is installed, this option will obey that addon's visibility settings for dead bodies--which will only show a marker on bodies whose map markers are visible to the player.
Enable special icon for explosive objects
If this option is enabled, explosive objects will use a special "I explode" icon instead of the standard dot markers.
Enable special icon for mutant-skinning prompt
If this option is enabled, the prompt to skin a mutant will use its own special icon instead of the standard dot markers.
If this option is enabled, stashes will use a classic stash icon instead of the standard dot markers when their primary interaction prompt is shown.
Enable special icon for breakable boxes
If this option is enabled, breakable boxes will use a special "breakable object" icon instead of the standard dot markers.
Enable special icon for talking to NPCs
If this option is enabled, stalkers will use a special "speech bubble" icon instead the standard dot marker when the prompt to engage them in dialogue is shown.
Enable special icons for service NPCs
If this option is enabled, service NPCs will use a service-specific icon instead of the standard dot markers when their primary interaction prompt is shown.
If this option is enabled, doors will use their own special icon instead of the standard dot markers when their primary interaction prompt is shown.
Enable special icons for task objectives
If this option is enabled, objects that are the target of the current active task will use a hi-res task marker icon instead of the standard dot markers.
The duration, in milliseconds, of the fade-in effect for interaction prompts.
The duration, in milliseconds, of the fade-out effect for interaction prompts.

If enabled, a small display will be shown beside the primary interaction prompt, showing its weight and value and (optionally, with Utjan's addon) indicator dots for the condition of weapon/armor parts.

If enbabled, the condition of weapons will be appended to the name of the item.\n
\nThis option is disabled by default in GAMMA, which does not use weapon condition.
If enbabled, the condition of outfits, headgear, and other non-weapon objects will be appended to the name of the item.
If enabled, the battery charge of devices will be appended to the name of the item.
If enabled, the color of the condition/battery text will change based on the value.
Show icon for favorites/junk on the item card
If enabled, items marked as Favorites or Junk with Sorting Plus will display the appropriate icon on the item card.
Some fonts will look better at different resolutions due to the inconsistent way Anomaly sizes the text. The default for the prompt text is Letterica 16, but choose whichever one looks best to you.
Font used for the Item Card

Some fonts will look better at different resolutions due to the inconsistent way Anomaly sizes the text. The default for the Item Card is the Small Print font, but choose whichever one looks best to you. \n \nThe addon tries to adjust the UI based on the size of the text, but it may be necessary to adjust screen position values for the Item Card or other elements when using some fonts.

The Item Card is an optional info window attached to the prompt that shows vital data such as an item's weight and value, as well as integrating with other addons such as Sorting Plus and Utjan's Item UI Improvements.
Changes the size of the icons in the Item Card, used for attributes such as Weight and Value. \n \nDefault: 7.5
Adjusts the amount that the Item Card's position is horizontally offset. \n \nDefault: -5
Adjusts the amount that the Item Card's position is vertically offset. \n \nDefault: -2

Adjusts the horizontal offset for the part condition dots added by Utjan's Item UI Improvements addon. This position is measured relative to the end of the primary text prompt.\n
\nDefault: -2

Adjusts the vertical offset for the part condition dots added by Utjan's Item UI Improvements addon. This position is measured relative to the end of the primary text prompt.\n
\nDefault: 9

Adjusts the horizontal offset for the Favorite/Junk icons added by Sorting Plus. This position is measured relative to the right end of the Item Card, which is based on the length of the longest text field: Weight or Value. \n \nDefault: 10

Adjusts the vertical offset for the Favorite/Junk icons added by Sorting Plus. This position is measured relative to the right end of the Item Card, which is based on the length of the longest text field: Weight or Value. \n \nDefault: 1

\nIf you find that your primary interact isn't registering when trying to quickly pick up multiple items, you can try lowering this value. It must be between 50 and 2000.

\nWhen using FDDA, this is necessary in order to allow the pickup animation time to complete. This setting should have no effect without FDDA installed.
The duration of the elastic pop-in animation that plays when focus is transferred to a marker. Can be up to 2000ms. Setting to zero will disable the feature.

If iTheon's Auto Looter is installed, enabling this option will cause the "Take all from container" secondary action to instead trigger Autoloot. Once this is done, the prompt for that body/stash will change to the normal take-all prompt.

If iTheon's Auto Looter is installed, and both Autoloot options are enabled in this menu, DotMarks will attempt to completely disable the Autoloot keybind.\n
\nFor some reason, Autoloot takes over the Alt key by default--it's bad behavior to hijack a basic modifier key like Alt that is used in hundreds of key combos. This option will free up that keybind, while still allowing you to trigger Autoloot via secondary action.
Enables the secondary action that allows you to immediately use any consumable pickup item.
Enables the secondary action that allows you to unload and take the ammunition from a weapon on the ground.

Enables the secondary action that allows you to take everything from a container at once.\n
\nIf you have iTheon's Auto Looter addon installed, there is also an option in the Addons menu that allows you to autoloot the same way. It is enabled by default.

Enables the secondary action that allows you to heal a wounded stalker on the ground.\n
\nUnlike the vanilla function, this will allow you to use any kind of medkit or stimpack you have--but it will always try to use the cheapest one, and it will show you on the prompt which one it will use, as well as how many uses you have remaining.
If you have the Animated NPC Healing addon installed, this option enables an animation when healing wounded stalkers using the secondary action.
If you have the Artfacts Inspection addon installed, this option enables its inspect animation as a secondary action for any marked artefacts.
Size of the part condition dots
This slider adjusts the size of the part condition dots in DotMarks. A value of 1 is their default intended size, while zero will hide these icons entirely.
Sets the alpha (transparency) channel for the drop shadows underneath the part condition dots. Set to zero to disable their drop shadows.

Sets the default placement mode for IEDs deployed using a secondary action, or disables that action to make it unavailable.


When targeting an undeployed IED pickup item, you can use the Fire Mode keybinds to cycle placement mode, and the mouse wheel to set the duration of the timer.


The remote detonator option requires the Remote Controlled Explosives addon.
Treat all squad members as talkative

In vanilla Anomaly, only the leader of a given squad can engage in conversation. Enable this setting if you have installed any addon which removes this leader-only restriction, such as the "Talk to Everyone" install option in Modular Miscellaneous Tweaks.\n \nThis setting is enabled by default in GAMMA, which includes that addon.

This setting allows you to adjust the amount of horizontal space that DotMarks assumes is required by the current fonts.\n
\nFonts are just textures in Anomaly, and some fonts are taller or wider than others. You may need to adjust this if you are at a resolution other than 1920x1080, install a custom font addon, or change to a different font than the default.

This setting allows you to adjust the amount of vertical space that DotMarks assumes is required by the current fonts.\n
\nFonts are just textures in Anomaly, and some fonts are taller or wider than others. You may need to adjust this if you are at a resolution other than 1920x1080, install a custom font addon, or change to a different font than the default.

This slider adjusts the scale of the UI's graphical elements, such as the keybind icon. This has no effect on the font size, but it can be used to fine-tune the GUI to account for your resolution or fonts.

By default, the part dots are arranged radially in a tight circle. You can instead choose to draw them as a horizontal or vertical line, but you'll probably want to adjust their positioning afterwards.

Welcome to %c[pda_yellow]Interaction Dot Marks%c[ui_gray_1]--a modernized replacement for the object interaction UI that brings some of Stalker 2's QoL features back to Anomaly, while adding powerful new options.


Except not quite as cool as Stalker 2, because Anomaly is jank. Hopefully this makes it a little less jank, and helps drag Anomaly's interaction UI kicking and screaming to somewhere within a decade of the modern world.


Everyone enjoys different things of course, so DotMarks is designed to be %c[pda_blue]customized to your preferences%c[ui_gray_1]--virtually every feature can be disabled or changed to your liking in the MCM menus, which also contain a wealth of information in the tooltips for each feature.


If you prefer to keep your HUD clean, you can even turn off all the visible markers, and still get the nicer interaction prompts and secondary actions.


%c[pda_yellow]It's your game. Play it your way.


%c[ui_gray_1]From %c[pda_yellow]MCM %c[pda_white]> %c[pda_yellow]Interaction Dot Marks%c[ui_gray_1]:

%c[pda_white] %c[pda_blue]General Settings%c[ui_gray_1]: Settings that control whether and how the core elements of the interaction UI are shown. If there's a particular detail you do or don't want to see, you'll probably find it here.

%c[pda_white] %c[pda_blue]Secondary Interact%c[ui_gray_1]: Settings related the the Secondary Interact function and its associated keybind, as well as whether or not each of the new actions is enabled.

When this setting is enabled, DotMarks will register a simple (unmodified) press even if the player was holding down the Shift key at the time. This allows you to rebind Shift to something else (e.g. Sprint) and use it on its own.\n
\nWhen disabled, a simple press will occur even while holding Shift. This allows you to use Shift in key combos without triggering unwanted duplicate actions.

When this setting is enabled, DotMarks will register a simple (unmodified) press even if the player was holding down the Ctrl key at the time. This allows you to rebind Ctrl to something else (e.g. Crouch) and use it on its own.\n
\nWhen disabled, a simple press will occur even while holding Ctrl. This allows you to use Ctrl in key combos without triggering unwanted duplicate actions.

When this setting is enabled, DotMarks will register a simple (unmodified) press even if the player was holding down the Alt key at the time. This allows you to rebind Alt to something else (e.g. Autoloot) and use it on its own.\n
\nWhen disabled, a simple press will occur even while holding Alt. This allows you to use Alt in key combos without triggering unwanted duplicate actions.
If enabled, this setting will hide the icon and/or text that indicates which keybind to press.
Show part condition dots for weapons
If enabled, the part condition dots from Utjan's Item UI Improvements addon will be shown on the prompt for weapons.
Show part condition dots for armor
If enabled, the part condition dots from Utjan's Item UI Improvements addon will be shown on the prompt for armor and headgear.
If enabled, markers for stashes that weren't created by the player will not be shown until the player has "discovered" that stash by causing its interaction prompt to appear.

If enabled, DotMarks will add a small amount of data to the savegame in order to track details such as which stashes the actor has already discovered.\n
\nRegardless of this setting, it is ALWAYS safe to add or remove DotMarks at any time during your playthrough.
